filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of Blake’s water color illustrations to the plays of William Shakespeare.
Although less extensive and well known than his illustrations of John Milton’s poems, Blake’s water colors based on Shakespeare’s plays constitute a significant group of designs. The earliest, dating from c. 1779, is probably one of Blake’s illustrations of English history but nonetheless evokes Shakespeare’s King Lear. The series of seven small ovals picturing characters from the plays also dates from Blake’s early years. The concentrated focus on just one or two figures filling most of the pictorial space may be Blake’s response to popular interest in miniature portraiture. The reason for his execution of this group is not known; like the English history designs, they may have been intended for eventual publication as engravings. The series of Shakespeare character portraits by John Hamilton Mortimer, published as engravings in the mid-1770s, may have influenced Blake’s similar project.
Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing is one of Blake’s largest water colors of the 1780s. Its size and quality suggest that it may have been intended for exhibition, like the water colors illustrating the life of Joseph displayed at the Royal Academy in 1785. The circle of dancers and Puck’s stance with arms raised echo similar motifs in George Romney’s Leveson-Gower Family, painted in 1776-77 and published as a mezzotint by John Raphael Smith in 1781.
Blake was clearly attracted to the vision of Queen Katherine in Henry VIII, act 4, scene 2, for he executed four versions beginning c. 1783-90 and concluding with the highly finished and complex water color of c. 1825-26. Blake’s water color of Queen Katherine’s dream dated 1809 is part of a series of six illustrations to Shakespeare’s plays commissioned by Joseph Thomas, the clergyman who had earlier employed Blake to illustrate Milton’s Comus and Paradise Lost. In a letter of 31 July 1801 to William Hayley, John Flaxman added a postscript to Blake, including the following: “he [Thomas] also desired you [Blake] will make two designs in bister or Indian Ink, from Shakespeare’s Troylus &amp Cressida, Coriolanus, either of the 3 plays of Henry 6.th Richard the 3.d or Henry the 8.th each design for one play for which he will give a Guinea each, the dimensions as follow the paper. an upright square of 12 Inches &amp half by 8 Inches, within this Space leaving a moderate margin, the principal figure not exceeding 6 Inches high” (Butlin 547). Blake’s designs (most now trimmed) roughly follow these size requirements, necessitated by Thomas’s desire to create an extra-illustrated copy of the 1632 second folio of Shakespeare’s plays, but Blake waited eight years before completing the commission, changed the medium from monochrome drawings to water colors, and illustrated only two plays, Richard III and Henry VIII, specified by Flaxman. Blake may have chosen the other passages for illustration, at some point convincing Thomas of their appropriateness.
Many of Blake’s Shakespeare designs show his predilection for scenes dealing with perceptions that extend beyond the world of the physical senses. The four versions of Queen Katherine’s dream epitomize this lifelong interest in imaginative and visionary experiences. A corollary is Blake’s attraction to representations of the arts, demonstrated by Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing and his portrayal of Pegasus, the classical embodiment of poetic inspiration, in As If an Angel Dropped Down from the Clouds among the designs for Thomas.

desc.objtitle: Oberon and Titania, Preceded by Puck, Object 1 (Butlin 246.1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five figures fly or hover against a starry sky in this illustration of Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. The rightmost figure flies right but turns to face forward with both arms bent and raised, with palms facing forward and fingers spread. The figure is male with short, perhaps curly hair and an open mouth. He may be speaking and leading the other figures to the right. He wears a shirt, breeches, and a red cape or cloak; a sword is visible against his left hip. Both legs are bent slightly with his right leg extended backward at left. He is likely Puck, the sprite assistant to Oberon, King of the Fairies. In the center of the composition, a pair of figures fly to the right or hover. They are likely Oberon and Titania, the king and queen of the Fairies in the play. Titania, the female figure at right, has long hair and wears a gown. Although she faces right, she turns forward perhaps to look toward her companion. Her left arm is straight and by her side. Her legs are together and extended horizontally at left. To her left, a male figure, likely Oberon, faces right. He has long hair and a beard and wears a crown, long gown, and red cape or cloak. With his right arm, which is bent and at his side, he holds a scepter. His left arm may be bent by his side, perhaps under his cape; he may hold an orb(?) with this hand in front of his lower torso. Both legs are together and extended to the left. To the left of this pair, two small gowned female figures, probably fairies, also fly right and hold the trains of the king and queen's gowns with raised, bent arms. The figure at right has long hair and may wear a garland on her head. She turns her head to look left, likely toward her companion, who also has long hair and wears a headband or garland on her head. Both figures extend their legs to the left. Below the five figures, there appears to be an area of dark ground or earth, and behind them, dark sky with stars, suggesting the time is night, perhaps at the conclusion of the play when Oberon and Titania lead the Fairies away and Puck concludes: "So good night unto you all./ Give me your hands, if we be friends,/ And Robin shall restore amends." (Act 5, Scene 1, 453-455).

She may wear a blue cloak, as evinced by the blue cloth held by the small figure to the left and a slender arc of blue below and to the right of Titania's left hip. Her legs are together and extended horizontally at left.

The central male figure in this scene, Oberon, holds a scepter in his right hand and may hold an orb(?) in his left hand, held near his lower torso. These, along with his crown, likely attest to his status as king of the Fairies.

Near the left side of the design, two small gowned female figures, probably fairies, fly right and hold the trains of the king and queen's gowns with raised, bent arms. Their bodies are almost horizontal. The figure at right has long hair and may wear a garland on her head. She turns her head to look left, likely toward her companion. Both figures extend their legs to the left.
